definition[0]: to prevent someone from leaving a room or building by locking the door
example[1]: They locked the director in his office.
definition[1]: to do something so that a price, offer, agreement etc cannot be changed
example[2]: Sell your stocks now to lock in some of the gains of recent months.
definition[2]: to make the taste, liquid etc remain in something
example[3]: This method of cooking locks in the flavour of the meat.
definition[3]: to gain something and be certain to keep it
example[4]: Investors can lock in an 8.4% yield on a 30-year Treasury Bond.
example[5]: Venezuela is seeking to lock in buyers for its oil.
definition[4]: to come to a firm agreement that will last for some time and cannot be broken
example[6]: Many homeowners are keen to lock in at current low interest rates.
